importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Madari Space's first mission is scheduled for 2026, marking a key milestone in the development of space-based data centers.
Lonestar Data Holdings plans to launch its first moon-based data center in 2027, positioned at the Earth-moon Lagrange point L1.
China launched 12 satellites for a space-based computing constellation in May, signaling the beginning of a large-scale effort to process data in space.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The data center power demand is projected to increase by 165% by 2030, driving urgency for alternative solutions like space-based data centers.
Advocates predict that almost all new data centers will be built in space within 10 years due to terrestrial energy constraints.

keyTakeAways: Advances in AI are driving massive demand for data centers, which currently require vast land and energy, leading to high CO2 emissions.
Space-based data centers offer access to continuous solar energy, avoiding cloud cover, night, and seasonal variability.
The ASCEND project in Europe is researching feasibility, with Thales Alenia Space finding that space-based solutions could offer a more eco-friendly and sovereign data hosting alternative.
Madari Space and Starcloud are launching small computing payloads into orbit as technical demonstrations; Madari plans to deploy a constellation of data satellites by 2026.
China launched 12 satellites in May 2025 as the first phase of a 2,800-satellite computing constellation.
Lonestar Data Holdings successfully tested a small data center on the moon in March 2025, with plans to launch six satellites by 2027 at the Earth-moon Lagrange point L1.
Starcloud will launch a satellite with an Nvidia H100 GPU in November 2025, aiming to set a record for in-orbit compute power.
A major challenge is heat dissipation in a vacuum and radiation damage to hardware in space.

Critics like Quentin A. Parker from HKU argue that terrestrial data centers remain cheaper and more practical; space-based systems face high costs, radiation risks, debris, and maintenance difficulties.
Experts warn about the growing space debris problem and the potential for geopolitical conflicts via counterspace technologies.

namedEntities.name: ASCEND
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A European project studying the feasibility of space-based data centers to reduce CO2 emissions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ASCEND project is central to evaluating whether space-based data centers can offer a cleaner, more sustainable alternative to terrestrial ones.

namedEntities.name: Thales Alenia Space
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A France-based company that led a European Commission-funded study on the ASCEND project.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Thales Alenia Space provided technical insights into how space-based data centers could leverage continuous solar energy and improve data sovereignty.

namedEntities.name: Madari Space
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Abu Dhabi-based startup collaborating with Thales Alenia Space to launch small computing payloads into orbit.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Madari Space is demonstrating early technical feasibility of space-based data centers, with a 2026 launch planned and a future constellation goal.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation launching a large-scale space-based computing constellation with 12 satellites in May 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China's launch marks a significant step toward deploying a large in-orbit computing network, indicating active state-led investment in space computing.

namedEntities.name: Lonestar Data Holdings
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Florida-based firm that successfully tested a small data center on the moon and plans to launch satellites at the Earth-moon Lagrange point L1.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lonestar is pioneering real-world testing of moon-based data centers, signaling a tangible path toward off-planet data infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: Starcloud
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Washington state-based startup launching a satellite with an Nvidia H100 GPU in November 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Starcloud aims to establish the most powerful in-orbit compute system, setting a benchmark for space-based processing capabilities.

namedEntities.name: SpaceX
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A private aerospace company providing launch vehicles and rideshares for space-based data center missions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SpaceX enables the launch of data center satellites through Falcon rockets, which are critical to reducing payload costs via shared rides.

namedEntities.name: Sidus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A spacecraft provider that has signed a $120 million deal with Lonestar to build and support six on-orbit data storage satellites.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sidus is a key partner in the logistics and deployment of Lonestar’s moon-based data center infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: UN Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international body promoting access to space for all, including through initiatives like the Access to Space for All.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: UNOOSA's initiative provided the launch platform for Madari Space’s first mission, emphasizing global participation in space-based tech development.

namedEntities.name: Goldman Sachs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A financial institution that projected a 165% increase in data center power demand by 2030.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Goldman Sachs’ data provides a key economic and demand-driven rationale for exploring space-based alternatives to terrestrial data centers.

namedEntities.name: Quentin A. Parker
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of the Laboratory for Space Research at the University of Hong Kong, who has raised skepticism about the economic viability of space data centers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Parker offers a critical perspective, highlighting cost, risk, and environmental concerns that challenge the feasibility of space-based computing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As artificial intelligence drives unprecedented demand for data centers, terrestrial facilities face growing challenges related to land scarcity, energy consumption, and carbon emissions. In response, several companies and organizations are exploring space-based solutions that leverage continuous solar energy and avoid terrestrial constraints. Projects like the European ASCEND initiative and startups such as Madari Space, Starcloud, and Lonestar Data Holdings are advancing technical demonstrations and deployment plans for small-scale computing in orbit or on the moon. While proponents argue that space-based data centers offer long-term sustainability and faster data processing, critics highlight economic inefficiencies, radiation risks, heat management challenges, and the growing problem of space debris. Despite skepticism, momentum is building, with China and private firms launching early experiments and setting ambitious timelines for future constellations. The sector remains in its infancy, with major hurdles in cost, technology, and safety, but the convergence of AI demand and space innovation suggests that space-based data centers could become a viable alternative to Earth-based infrastructure within the next decade.
title: Why these companies want to send data centers into space
